reviews.review:
Um dos FPS que mais revolucionou os games está de volta em Half-Life 2!
Gráficos bonitos, mecânicas novas (para a época). Ótimo enredo, simplesmente incrível!

Ok now that I've finished it.  I love it.  I hated the "Follow Freeman!" chapter because of the amount of striders but it didn't bring down my enjoyment too much.  It is an amazing game and a must play.  Just buy it.
Definitely should be in your game library.

это шикарная вселенная игровой индустрии, её можно бесконечно проходить, но самое главное это игра была очень превосходна для 2004 года с её сюжетной линии и посей день, сюжет очень пасмурный, печальный, но куда без проблем? так что я рекомендую купить и пройти эту игру и посмотреть все её детали.

As someone who was born in 2003 i was obviously not able to play this game when it was released. Through the years ive heard how great this game was and that everyone should at least try it. So here in 2020 I finally decided to play this game. I can now say this is one of the best games ive ever played. The seamless story telling that is always connected to the gameplay is amazing. The story had me engaged the way through and the way it was expanded in episode one and episode two is great. I enjoyed the gunplay well enough and the selection of weapons is nice. I do wish though there were more weapons like the crossbow (My favorite weapon in the game). The game is 16 years old but when I played the visuals impressed me greatly, and though the textures are outdated they still holed up pretty well. I can say that this game was an amazing experience and im glad i finally decided to play it. I highly recommend this game to anyone who has not played it and Im looking forward for what comes next.

I'm like 16 years late, had HL2 on previous accounts, but I strongly believe it's important for everyone who likes video games to play this one and always remember about the signifcancy of its consequences which are scattered across the industry, therefore I feel obligated to at least depict why Half Life 2 is still considered, after so many years, as a Holy Grail of gaming. 
 Starting off with lore, there are not many stories, nor characters out there coming from video games that are consistently greater than the ones from Half Life. What you will be presented with during your stay in and out of CIty 17 is an amazing world building, delivered by scary, gloomy and stuffed with feeling of infirmity landscape, scenes of powerful pain which has been brought upon the Earth by final moments of the first Half Life. To keep things short, basically what happened was a big nuclear collapse situated on our planet caused by omniscient G-Man, which eventually led to the invasion by stranger intergalactic force known as the Combine. Because of technological advantage, Combine conquered Earth in a short span of 7 hours and began their reign of terror. The protagonist you play as, dr Gordon Freeman, all of a sudden finds himself inside of a workers' train, after 20 years of being kept outside of normal timeline, but it also turns out that rebels have awaited you for all of this time and are ready to give you your main goal - freeing every living being from the emotionless hands of regime. The world you are about to explore from now on is a beautiful collage of gray, seemingly meaningless buildings, almost empty alleys that used to be full of lights and life, petrifying canals, sewers, abandoned roads and towns full of undead, crawling evil. With that being said, some of you may ask how is it even possible? Altough the game was released back in 2004, it's still super realistic, textures are on point, because they are simple yet sophisticated, they're always balancing between hyperrealism and hallucinating vibes straight out of nightmares. 
 Graphics, lights and shadows were done perfectly, but the thing that distinguishes typical brainless shooters of that era from Half Life 2 is game's physics. Shortly after release it even got to a point where everyone was mesmerized by how well physichal laws work in this game. I think it's fair to say that Half Life 2 was the first FPS game that allowed player to not only vacantly follow the path of murder, but also have fun and have a real impact on the entourage around. Nowadays some of the physics appear to be glitchy, but 'til this day equipment like Gravity Gun allows users to become a master of their own mind playing something that isn't even real which can only be described as a transcendence of video gaming quality. 
 Level design is extremely clever, knows when the momentum needs to be carried, when to slow things down a little and last but not least, it crosses barriers in terms of how a good story should be told. Games are after all a totally different medium from movies, music etc. therefore they should be allowed to have their own storytelling pace and tools to craft an epic adventure. Only thing I didn't enjoy though was the length of Route Canals, this segment should've been way shorter, but I'll let that one slide.
 Story might be perceived as simplistic, but I personally refuse to believe that the main plot functions in this game as a foreground. I think the essence of Half Life is hidden between the environment and the story of yourself, depending on how you play throughout the game. It's a symbolic journey, woven with mysteries, some things are not clear yet ( that's also probably why half of PC gamers wait for the continuation ), but there are scenes which emphasize the spiritual voyage of Freeman and yourself, such as entering the Citadel which is very similar to first moments of the first Half Life, suggesting that all of the things you've been through were ultimately supposed to lead you to this very moment. Even though some of the dialogues might seem dry by today standards, Valve handled things really well by adding to the game really good facial expressions that hadn't been seen until then, so I personally think the lack of some character development was repaid by another revolutionary idea.
 I really think sound effects and OST in this game are underrated big time and by that I mean that a lot of players mainly focus on mechanics or gameplay while talking about this masterpiece, but audio is what truely keeps every single element of the game together like a glue. SFX can scare you, make you feel so lonely or simply put you into this overwhelming, creepy vibe that is much needed in order to experience Half Life's world in full spectrum.
 Y'all better buckle up, because Half Life 2 is gonna take you on a very exciting ride. Everything that is even remotely considered as fun is in this game. Decent weapon choice, classic crowbar, rocket launcher, HE grenades, suit with flashlight and boost, crossbow and this weird thing for huge ants, but most importantly - the Gravity Gun, which allows you to create a death tool from almost everything. The game also has very naturally feeling cause and effect sequence, which makes you forget about how scripted Half Life is. The only thing I always hated are ladders, they are kinda clunky, but overall gameplay is very smooth and enjoyable.
 No matter what you do in HL2, playing around with Gravity Gun, killing hostiles while jumping like a rabbit in HEV suit or just admiring the views, the experience is like nothing else and that's why it will always remain as an absolute masterpiece. When I was trying to get a certain achievement in the game, I stumbled upon a YouTube video with a good comment under it that sums it up pretty well. It said:
"2004 - beautiful game
2020 - beautiful game"   𝟭𝟭/𝟭𝟬

Valve can't stop putting out great games.
buy it now your life will be better. 
its just an amazing game.
